item.title: Theory: State aggregation or discretization or quantization
item.description: So far, we have studied exact solutions to the dynamic program. When the state space is large (or possibly continuous), an exact solution is not possible due to computational limitations. So, we need to look at approximate solutions. The simplest form of approximate solution is state aggregation, in which we partition the state space into equivalence classes and assign one state in each class as a representative element of that class.

item.title: Theory: Feature abstraction in MDPs
item.description: Consider an MDP with continuous state space \(\ALPHABET X\) and finite action space \(\ALPHABET U\). We denote this MDP by \(M = (\ALPHABET X, \ALPHABET U, c, p)\), where for simplicity we assume that the \(p\) is the density of the transition kernel. Since the state space is continuous, in general, we cannot compute the value functions exactly. The simplest way to proceed is to discretize the state space \(\ALPHABET X\).

item.title: Theory: Model approximation in MDPs
item.description: There are many instances where we may plan using an approximate model.
